DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Thousands Bid Farewell to Sakharov
LaserPhotos MOSB5,6; MOS5,14
DOC.TEXT: After a kiss from his widow, Andrei D. Sakharov was buried Monday in a snowy cemetery where Kremlin elite joined with common people in mourning the human rights advocate once treated as an outlaw. To the baleful strains of Robert Schumann's ``Traumerai,'' Sakharov's coffin was carried along a path strewn with evergreen boughs to the freshly dug grave at Vostryakovskoye Cemetery. ``It's over,'' Sakharov's wife and dissident comrade-in-arms, Yelena Bonner, said as she turned to a companion during the twilight burial under pines dripping with rain. Sakharov died Thursday of an apparent heart attack at the age of 68. He was buried alongside Bonner's mother, Ruth, a Stalin-era political prisoner who died in 1987 at age 87. Before the crimson- and black-trimmed coffin was lowered into the cold land Sakharov tried so hard to change, its lid was removed to allow Bonner a last farewell. She took the shroud from his face and bent to kiss him on the forehead. As the procession wound its way through Moscow, some mourners marched alongside with signs demanding democratic elections, one of Sakharov's final causes. Others hoisted the blue, red, and white flag of czarist Russia, now the symbol of the grassroots pro-democracy Russian People's Front. Top Communist Party brass riding sleek black limousines and tens of thousands of common people trudging through the slush joined in paying their last respects to the Nobel Peace laureate, who once was pilloried as an ignoramus and dupe of the West. In the morning, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other members of the ruling Politburo stood in the rain to view the body outside the Academy of Sciences. Sakharov, a creator of the Soviet hydrogen bomb, was a member of the academy. Gorbachev spoke at length there with Bonner and later told reporters: ``Now it is clear that he deserved the Nobel Prize.'' Sakharov won the prize in 1975 for his human rights campaign, but the Soviet leadership at the time refused to let him go to Norway to accept it. He was hounded for years and finally sent into internal exile in Gorky for nearly seven years. An open-ended bus followed by thousands of mourners carried Sakharov's body and Bonner along Lenin Prospekt to outdoor funeral ceremonies in the parking lot of the Luzhniki sports complex, a favorite site for rallies by human rights activists. More than 30,000 people surged forward toward Sakharov's carnation-bedecked coffin, and Bonner had to plead for order. Sakharov ``did all he could,'' Ilya Zaslavsky, a Moscow member of the Congress of People's Deputies, told the crowd. ``Now only his ideas can change things, and only we can fulfill his ideas.'' ``The Academy of Sciences is guilty before him; we were passive in our defense of him,'' Sakharov's fellow academician and Congress member, Dmitri Likhachev, said in a quavering voice. ``Now we say: Andrei Dmitrievich, forgive us!'' State-run TV showed excerpts of the Luzhniki services in a special broadcast of the kind usually reserved for the deaths of major government figures. The evening news program ``Vremya'' led off with an eight-minute report on Sakharov's last rites, accompanied by a sorrowful dirge. The 2,250-member Congress, or parliament, to which Sakharov belonged adjourned at midday so its members could attend the funeral ceremonies. From Luzhniki, the coffin was transported nine miles in a bus to the cemetery along slush-filled streets. In addition to Gorbachev, Politburo members and other Soviet leaders gathered at the Academy of Sciences to view Sakharov's body. From another direction, buses escorted by police cars arrived. Some 20 people carried the casket on their shoulders from a bus and placed it on a bier in front of the academy. Bonner also emerged, accompanied by her son, Alexei Semenov. The coffin was opened in the frigid rain, and an umbrella opened to shield Sakharov's face. A bareheaded and somber Gorbachev walked to the foot of the casket and stood for awhile in silence. He bowed twice, and the huddle of people around the casket broke up. Gorbachev and Bonner spoke animatedly, with Bonner smiling at one point. Gorbachev and his entourage entered the academy Presidium building to sign an official book of condolences. He wrote simply, ``M.S. Gorbachev.'' He emerged and talked briefly with reporters. ``The relations between myself and Sakharov were always those of mutual respect,'' Gorbachev said. ``Now it is clear that he deserved the Nobel Prize.'' It was Gorbachev who allowed Sakharov to return to Moscow in December 1986 after the years of exile in Gorky. The two men had clashed, however, over the speed and sweep of Gorbachev's political reform program, with Sakharov demanding the Communist Party that Gorbachev heads renounce its constitutional monopoly on power. Some parliamentarians Monday pledged to heed Sakharov's call to create a full-fledged opposition in the Congress and to push for victory for progressives in nationwide local elections that began this month. Lech Walesa, the leader of Poland's Solidarity movement and winner of the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize, had been expected to attend the service, but Poland's official PAP news agency reported his plane had to land in Leningrad because of bad weather.
